placement of man made obstacles. it seems like there is always a 90 degree corner immediately after obstacles that require some sort of speed. it seems like some trails are built intentionally to keep speed down(?). if this is the intention they’re nailing it, i understand that safety is a priority. but if they are trying to build flowy trails that people at higher levels can ride quickly, then it’s a fail.

progression. for too many years morc has catered to the entry level riders and given no opportunity to progress as a rider. it's been getting much better in the last few years. nice to see!

trail mainteance beyond volunteers; ask for money! ski trail requires passes! morc and/or the parks could ask for a $10-25 membership  (with always an option for financial aid), and i am sure people would buy it. they do it for state park parking; they do it for nordic skiing. mtb riders take too much for granted!
find places to ride when wet

an awareness for a demand of a connected dirt trail system msp: 

first, a connected dirt vision is needed. we have incredible stand-alone trails in msp but what is the plan for connecting these trail "islands" with dirt?"   i and friends/family spend money to ride cuyuna, duluth, hayward, bentonville, kingdom trails, etc.  each has a different development model and has exploded in the past 10 years. morc could lead the way in evolving a vision for a msp dirt network.
  
second,   school-based trails are the future. we have an incredibly vibrant array of school-based club mtb programs in msp.  mca (minnesota cycling association) parents (coaches) and athletes are highly engaged in the sport.  parents ride, teachers ride, etc. many district have plenty of land could be part of the overall msp dirt vision.  this trail vision doesn't need to be sprayed, mowed and manicured for the friday night lights, it can be ridden and raced anytime by anyone.

lastly, having been riding trails in the upper midwest since 1984, i am not the future of msp dirt..... but kids certainly are!  we purchased a home 8 years ago so my kids could  be closer, and ride to a dirt trail.  we're thankful for the ability to do that, but not everyone has this opportunity.  a connected system in msp could enable any kid or family to access the outdoors and trails.  

thanks for everything.  happy to help out with the next phase.

i'd love to see more time spent on battle creek - i know there's a lot of new trails going in in the next few years, but there's been, from my perspective, a bear complete lack of maintenance on the trail this year. they've been putting in new trail but places like wod, freight train, big wheezy and goat have major erosion issues that for a part of the summer were almost unrideable. alongside that, i try to stay in tune to the facebook page for bc as well as the local mountain bikers of minnesota page and i don't believe they've had a single organized trail session that wasn't with a nica group this year. i would've loved to help out due to the major issues we had this year but i felt like even though i wanted to, i wasn't able to - barring doing light maintenance (clearing branches, some small trees myself). speaking of trees - there were major trail-impeding trees down for multiple weeks in some areas at bc, although most of the trees that were around blind corners were taken care of fairly fast. i love bc and i probably ride it more than most but it's been less and less fun over the last year or so, and i'm concerned that these issues will get worse as there becomes more trail to maintain.

i don't want to just criticize though - i really would help on dig nights if they held them next year!
communicate why we should be members

i really enjoy the trails we have around here, but, trail closures. way too high and mighty closing the trails, and then whoever is in charge of reporting the trail won’t provide an update for sometimes 4-5 days (monarch for example last weekend, a brand new highly anticipated trail system and you can’t even update it for us???). the smallest bit of rain will close the trails sometimes. let people ride. it’s not just kids and families riding these trails on the weekends, it’s passionate, daily riders who aren’t concerned about riding some muddy trails, or a big scary rut popping up. i stopped my membership/donations because i hate paying for it when other people get to decide when i can and cannot do the thing i love most in life, and again can’t even take the time to ensure a backup plan or someone to help them update trail status daily.

too focused on building trails for the extreme riders who want bigger jumps and features. some of us just want to ride old school chonk with a bit of flow thrown in.  more importantly,  morc needs to take the lead on trail etiquette education and signage at trails. leb in particular has become so bro-culture that it drives newer riders and moms with kids away because it's not safe with all the strava dudes running kids off the trails. when i cut my teeth riding out west in the 90s, we self-enforced and educated newer riders on imba rules and basic trail decency. we seem to have lost that. a few ideas: signage at the trails emphasizing etiquette and setting forth the rules. partner with mca to require trail etiquette training (an actual class) and the signing of an etiquette agreement for all coaches, riders and parents.

since i used to visit the site all the time was an easy way for me to see if my membership was still active and when it was due. i assume i get emails that get lost in all the other emails that flow through.

trails that are accessible to someone like me who is a serious rider but not a man, not aggressive , and not middle aged. i’ve gotten a bit rusty lately and attempts to get back on the trail has been hard because some riders are a touch intimidating. i really want to improve and get back to my old form, so for now i’m a bit slow. even when i was younger and a lot faster some riders are lousy at their own skills of sharing trails. please, on some trails there has to be more places where someone can pass me with out me having to stop and pull over. it’s discouraging. the bro culture has gotten pretty thick. i do appreciate riders who exercise patience and are kind. flow = heaven. thanks for the survey.

allow the building of much more aggressive trails - large jumps, gaps, drops, tall skinnies - things for skilled riders to enjoy, and things for beginner and intermediate riders to work towards being able to ride. not everything needs to be beginner-friendly. 

there are so many people who are willing to put in the sweat to make this stuff happen. the hands and hours are there, not currently being utilized, because people don't want to get involved *only* to provide free yardwork. that stuff needs to happen, but nowhere near as frequently as some in morc think. more volunteers will be available to lighten the load for everyone if you can get people interested in helping to build better stuff. it won't be as bad then, for those new people to volunteer some time for the boring maintenance work once in a while.  

build these more aggressive trails that are marked "mandatory jumps/gaps/drops, ride at your own risk", etc. and then don't modify them later because some whiny local karens think everyone should be able to ride everything all the time. proper signage and best practices put into place and handling progression like ski/snowboard terrain parks is essential. there are *well established* guidelines for this stuff. 

people want to get involved, but only when getting involved will actually improve things and make trails more fun. there's no reason leb or elm or murphy or whatever can't have larger features simply built into existing trails, or off of them on optional lines catering to more advanced riders. the way the small rock roll at leb developed as a red option off to the side, rejoining the main trail just before the blue/black intersection - this should happen all over the place on every trail system. explore the woods, find cool lines, and allow features to be built as options. expansion to include optional lines that are more interesting has barely taken place at all. quite literally no reason this can't happen everywhere.
can’t think of anythjnf

y'all know the #1 (often the only) thing folks want and expect from morc is an accurate/current trail conditions update. it's clearly too much to expect volunteers will always be able to deliver this; it's beyond time to utilize the strength and wisdom of our community and crowdsource this. you/we can do it!
more direction to dirt bosses regarding best practice and standardization of trails: consistent signage, education, maps, wayfinding, etc. coordinate with land managers to allow this standardization. 
coordination with mca (hs cycling league). this is such a huge opportunity to connect with more riders (potential supporters, volunteers, members, etc). it's also crucial to ensuring a positive experience at the trail for all users. this will take some work to create/build/sustain relationships with staff and coaches, but as you already know, it's become a critical issues at many trails.
more fundraising. i renew my membership whenever i'm prompted to do so. it's now been years :((  that's the low-hanging fruit, but it hasn't been happening. every trail should have a q/r sign at the trailhead to invite donations. that would cost literally pennies to print/post that ask, more low-hanging fruit that's been missed. the gala-style event takes more work, but has value not-only for revenue but also gives you a real-world presence and provides value to members who participate. figure out what you're missing to pull this off, and get that going again. 
more bike parks in more places! this is absolutely the future of growing the sport, and would love to see morc taking a strong lead. devin and mike at mpls bike parks have developed/shown the blueprint for doing this successfully, morc needs to be stepping up as the more-established advocacy group and create more opportunities. this is where kids and families can get exposed to the sport, practice skills, and access off-road riding right in their neighborhoods, even if there isn't an official trail nearby. 
if the organizational capacity is the issue morc hasn't been able to do the above, it's no longer acceptable to use that as an excuse, and growing your capacity to do the needed work should be the focus. that could mean growing the board + working subcommittees, and/or returning to paid staff. there are various options that need to be considered, but throwing up hands and settling for a status quo that doesn't allow the organization to fulfill it's core functions can not be an option.
merch
need to trails for greater wet weather riding. less restrictive during wet weather.   all conditions riding improves ridership and decreases negative feedback.

bicycle advocacy, improved advertising so all mtn bikes know what morc stands for, better communication to notify member annual dues should be renewed(heard auto-renew is option so thanks for being creative & making this happen aka. simpler is better)

when i was a member communication was non-existent, not sure that has improved. morc needs to hold events to showcase what it does, fundraise and bring together the community. look at the fundraisers (coggs gala as example) that other groups do. when i did volunteer it did not make me want to do it frequently; the group was more exclusive than inclusive. currently i do not support what i would call the "dumbing down" of trails. features (rocks, roots, etc…) are too often removed or filled in reducing the technical aspects of the trails. entire rock gardens removed at murphy, things filled in at lebanon, etc…
skills clinic, coach certification
signage, trail markers
more timely trail conditions updates.
more organized
maybe fixing rutted out sections a little more often. honestly though i feel like it's hard to stay on top of. all of the other work outweighs the usual rough patches! keep up the great work!
battle creek gets overgrown often

i wish i was getting more communication, maybe some sort of email newsletter that has things like upcoming race events, kid events, general bike info. like skinnyski's midwest mtb coverage.

you should put on a twin cities race event
keep developing new trails
more miles
visibility of their work

perhaps updating trail conditions more often. maybe a reduced membership fee for someone to check trails and post an update each day during the season?
all good
trail education, more events, bring back 24 hour races
more rocky, rooty rugged trail (not just flow trail), skills parks for younger beginners
variety in trail style. everything is close to the same feeling. given our location, that’sa hard one to not do though.
